bibl.title: Despatch from R. Dorsey Mohew to Josiah Quiney, February 28, 1894
Despatches from United States Consuls in Boma, 1888-1895
bibl.publisher: National Archives and Records Service General Services Administration

div1.note: Indian Bureau Dept of State Jun 7 94
div1.p:
Commercial Agency of the United States,
Kongo Free State Kassongo February 28 1894

Mr R. Dorsey Mohun
To the Department of State.
Movements during past three months, also those of the future

Arrival at Kassongo
Departure for Lake Tanganyika

Commercial Agency of the United States,
Kongo Free State Kassongo February 22d 1894

Honorable Josiah Quincy
Assistant Secretary of State,
Washington, D.C.
I have the honor to inform the Department of my arrival at this place. February 26th from Stanley Falls.

From Novr 29th, the date of my last letter to the Department, I have traveled through most of the Mallela country lying between the Lomami & the Loualaba, & have been down the Loualaba to Stanley Falls & Basoko, returning to Kassongo by the same road.

The Arab was being about having been defeated and driven from the country, I shall have in a few days for the month of the Lukugu, 10 days south of here and follow the course of that river to the Tanganyika. This will occupy
occupy at least five months. On arrival at Mpala, I shall go to the North end of the Lake, & from there to the South and take the road to Nyassa, down the Lake to the Shire & on to Quelimene on the East Coast. I hope to be on the Coast about September 1st & if the Department permits will take steamer from there to the Cape of Good Hope & on to Boma to settle my affairs & return to America on leave.
I have a force of sixty soldiers with me armed with the Albini rifle & some hundred porters. I suppose the total number of people in my caravan may be put down at 250.
I am in the best of the health. I have had no letters or papers for ten months!

Respectfully
R. Dorsey Mohun
U. S. Commercial Agent

The Consul at Boma, Kongo Free State, reported under date of February 28 that he was at that time at Kassongo, on the Upper Kongo, and that he intended to proceed from there to Mpala, Lake Tanganyika, thence to the north end of the lake, thence south to the southern extremity of the lake, thence across the country to the northern extremity of Lake Nyassa, thence by the Shire river to the coast at Quilimane. He expects to reach Quilimane about the first of next September. We have a Consular Agent at Beira just south of Quilimane, and I suggest that we write to Mr. Mohun in care of the Consular Agent at Beira with instructions (to the agent) to send the letter to Quilimane. In this letter I think we shoud direct Mr. Mohun to return by water to Boma and settle his accounts; also that we should grant him sixty days leave of absence to come to the United States. He has been in the interior of Africa ever since his arrival in Boma about two years ago. He states that he has not received any communication whatever in ten months.
